trans-unit.source: Your network architect would like to take advantage of performance routing to ensure customers have the best performance.
They need you to deploy the Music Stream app into two more regions and configure performance routing.
World map showing the four endpoints, Central USA, West USA, East Asia, and Northern Europe
You'll now deploy the application into two more regions.
Then you'll create a new Traffic Manager to use all four endpoints.
Deploy additional instances and configure Traffic Manager
Create two new endpoints in Central US and North Europe by deploying the application to new instances of App Service in those regions.
Create a new Traffic Manager profile with performance routing.
Create four new endpoints that can use the deployed four web apps.
Navigate to the Traffic Manager profiles Fully Qualified Domain Name (FQDN), your request will be routed to the endpoint that responds with the lowest latency.
Depending on where you're located, you'll be directed to the best performing endpoint.
Screenshot of the running the closest web app to you
Use `nslookup` to resolve the Traffic Manager profile domain name.
`nslookup` will return where the domain name resolves to, for example if you're closest to Europe:
If your customers have two endpoints that have equal network latency, they could be routed to either endpoint.
Refresh your web page to see if you are served the same endpoint.
